qas.question: Why did the Kievan state prosper?

answers.text: abundant supply of furs, beeswax, honey, and slaves for export

qas.question: How many trade routes did the Kievan state control?
Which route was a central post in Kiev?
What other means of pay when purchasing items may have been in place?

plausible_answers.text: abundant supply of furs, beeswax, honey, and slaves for export

qas.question: What made the Kievan state deteriorate?
How many minor trade routes did the Kievan state control?
What was moved north on a network of rivers and short portages along the Dnieper?
What was the hub in the north-south overland trade route?

context: The new Kievan state prospered due to its <a0_0><b4_0>abundant supply of furs, beeswax, honey, and slaves for export<b4_0/><a0_0/>, and because it controlled <a1_0><b5_0>three<b5_0/><a1_0/> main trade routes of Eastern Europe. In the north, Novgorod served as a commercial link between the Baltic Sea and the Volga trade route to the lands of the Volga Bulgars, the Khazars, and across the Caspian Sea as far as Baghdad, providing access to markets and products from Central Asia and the Middle East. <b6_0>Trade<b6_0/> from the Baltic also moved south on a network of rivers and short portages along the Dnieper known as the "route from the Varangians to the Greeks," continuing to the Black Sea and on to Constantinople. <b7_0>Kiev<b7_0/> was a central outpost along the <a2_0>Dnieper route<a2_0/> and a hub with the east-west overland trade route between the Khazars and the Germanic lands of Central Europe. These commercial connections enriched Rus' merchants and princes, funding military forces and the construction of churches, palaces, fortifications, and further towns. Demand for luxury goods fostered production of expensive jewelry and religious wares, allowing their export, and an advanced credit and <a3_0>money-lending system<a3_0/> may have also been in place.
